title: 112_s2515
content: The Act may be cited as the "Clean Cookstoves Support Act of 2012". Congress finds that nearly half the world's population cooks over open fires or inefficient cookstoves, leading to health issues like respiratory illnesses and burns. Smoke from cooking fuels causes around 2,000,000 deaths annually in the developing world, surpassing deaths from malaria, tuberculosis, or HIV. Millions more suffer from toxic smoke exposure. The use of inefficient cookstoves leads to health issues and environmental problems. Women and children spend significant time collecting biomass fuel, risking violence as they travel farther to find resources. Black carbon from biomass cookstoves contributes to regional air pollution. Biomass cookstoves contribute significantly to regional air pollution and climate change, with black carbon emissions from residential cookstoves in developing countries accounting for 21% of the global inventory. The Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves, a public-private partnership led by the United Nations Foundation, aims to enable the adoption of clean and efficient stoves in 100 million homes by 2020 by raising $250 million to overcome market barriers. The United States Government has committed up to $105,000,000 over five years to support the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. This includes funding from various departments for promoting clean cookstoves, research on technologies, and health initiatives. The United States Government has allocated $2,180,000 for health research, $6,000,000 for stove testing and design, and up to $50,000,000 for clean energy projects through the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. The United States Government has allocated funds for health research, stove testing and design, and clean energy projects through the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. Additionally, there is a focus on advancing the goals of the alliance. The Secretary of State, in consultation with relevant agencies and organizations, will work to advance the goals of the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves through research, development, diplomatic engagement, and promoting consumer awareness. The Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves aims to improve consumer awareness, access to carbon financing, and support women-owned businesses. It also focuses on international development projects for clean stoves and fuels, efforts in refugee camps and disaster relief, and financing for projects providing clean energy access. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriations of not less than $11,570,000 for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 to address smoke exposure from traditional cookstoves, support research on improved stove technology and indoor air quality, and carry out other activities under this Act. The Secretary of Energy is authorized to allocate $12,500,000 for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves on research for low-emission, high-efficiency cookstoves. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to allocate $24,700,000 for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 for the National Institutes of Health to support research on the health effects of cookstove smoke. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to allocate funds for research on the health effects of cookstove smoke, including pulmonary, cancer, and cardiac diseases, low-birth weight, safety education, measuring devices, epidemiologic studies, clinical trials, training programs, and other related activities. The allocated amount is not less than $2,180,000 for fiscal years. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to allocate funds for research on the health effects of cookstove smoke, including pulmonary, cancer, and cardiac diseases, low-birth weight, safety education, measuring devices, epidemiologic studies, clinical trials, training programs, and other related activities. Additionally, the Environmental Protection Agency is authorized to allocate funds not less than $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves on various activities. The Environmental Protection Agency allocated funds from 2013 to 2017 to collaborate with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves on stove testing, design innovations, health assessments, and other related activities.
